channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SGF-195] colocated-with fails on partition region
item.description:
The colocated-with attribute on the <partitioned-region> element fails with the following exception:

Region specified in 'colocated-with' is not present. It should be created before setting 'colocated-with' to this region.

This is due to the order in which the regions are created. The colocated-with attribute specifies a region name, but the order in which the regions are created is dependent on the injection order, which may be different than the order in which the regions appear in the context file. This can happen when the regions are injected into a class using @Resource(name="")

The colocated-with attribute should specify the region bean name as a reference rather than the region name itself. This would ensure that the order in which the region beans are created is consistent with the dependency order that Gemfire requires when creating colocated regions.

Test project is attached.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The comments below are informational and meant to augment the details of this bug based on the description above...

This bug is due in part (implied in the description) to a limitation that is exposed by GemFire... that a Region (test2), defined to be colocated with another Region (test1), must be created after the Region (test1) with which it will be colocated.

In a GemFire context without Spring, the colocated Region (test2) must even be "declared" before the Region (test1) it will be colocated with. Unlike Spring, GemFire does not distinguish and cleanly separate between parsing/validating and creating GemFire objects (such as Regions) when processing a cache.xml.

With Spring, it parses/validates and then creates beans from the bean definitions in the app context, therefore, it is possible to define dependencies between collaborators (beans) defined in context where the declaration order does not match the dependency order. As such, dependencies can be defined later in the context than the dependent bean and still be resolved appropriately.

As an example, the following cache.xml will lead to the same problem...

<!DOCTYPE cache PUBLIC
 
  "-//GemStone Systems, Inc.//GemFire Declarative Caching 7.0//EN"
 
  "http://www.gemstone.com/dtd/cache7_0.dtd">
 
<cache>
 
  <region name="testOne" refid="PARTITION">
 
    <region-attributes>
 
      <partition-attributes colocated-with="testTwo"/>
 
    </region-attributes>
 
  </region>
 
  <region name="testTwo" refid="PARTITION"/>
 
</cache>

The result is (from GemFire's Server log)...

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Region specified in 'colocated-with' is not present. It should be created before setting 'colocated-with' to this region.
 
	at ...
 
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Region specified in 'colocated-with' is not present. It should be created before setting 'colocated-with' to this region.
 
	at com.gemstone.gemfire.internal.cache.PartitionAttributesImpl.validateColocation(PartitionAttributesImpl.java:582)
 
	at com.gemstone.gemfire.internal.cache.PartitionAttributesImpl.validateWhenAllAttributesAreSet(PartitionAttributesImpl.java:553)

This is the same problem when using GemFire in a Spring context as seen when running the "colocation-test" example app...

Exception in thread "main" org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'myService': Injection of resource dependencies failed; 
nested exception is org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'test2Region': Cannot create inner bean '(inner bean)' of type [org.springframework.data.gemfire.RegionAttributesFactoryBean] while setting bean property 'attributes'; 
nested exception is org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name '(inner bean)': Invocation of init method failed; 
nested exception is java.lang.IllegalStateException: Region specified in 'colocated-with' is not present. It should be created before setting 'colocated-with' to this region.
 
	at ...
 
Caused by: ... 
        at ...
 
        ... 18 more
 
Caused by: ...
 
	at ...
 
	... 33 more
 
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Region specified in 'colocated-with' is not present. It should be created before setting 'colocated-with' to this region.
 
	at com.gemstone.gemfire.internal.cache.PartitionAttributesImpl.validateColocation(PartitionAttributesImpl.java:582)
 
	at com.gemstone.gemfire.internal.cache.PartitionAttributesImpl.validateWhenAllAttributesAreSet(PartitionAttributesImpl.java:553)
 
	at ...
 
        ... 36 more

Here, the validation of value for colocated-with occurs within GemFire when evaluating the partitioned region attributes upon creating Region test2.

It is logical to set the 'colocated-with' attribute using a bean reference rather than just the bean name of the Region, as this would force the Spring Container to create and initialize Region test1 before the dependent Region test2 is created thereby satisfying the GemFire constraint involving colocated Regions. This would be similar to wiring collaborators in a Spring context using <property name="X" ref="myBean">, <property name="X"><ref bean="myBean"/> or <bean name="myBean" class="a.b.c.MyBean" p:X-ref="myBean"/>, and also similar in behavior to Springs "depends-on" attribute of a <bean/> element.

I am currently exploring the changes that would be necessary to treat the "colocated-with" attribute as bean reference.

It should be noted that this change would be more consistent with the Spring programming model and better hide the details of the GemFire API, where the colocatedWith property of PartitionAttributes is typed as String, corresponding to the Region name (path).

http://pubs.vmware.com/vfabric53/topic/com.vmware.vfabric.gemfire.7.0/reference/topics/cache_xml.html?path=4_1_9_1_2_12_8#partition-attributes

Possible workaround to this problem to follow...

And now the possible workaround...

In general, I would advise against using the public GemFire API directly in application code as was illustrated in the MyService class of the example application (in colocation-tests.zip) since this unnecessarily couples any Spring-based application to GemFire.

It is better to access a Region using Spring Data GemFire's org.springframework.data.gemfire.GemfireTemplate class. It is always possible to still get access to the GemFire Region class if necessary using the GemFireTemplate.getRegion() method.

By defining GemfireTemplates bean definitions for our GemFire Regions in the Spring app ctx, I am then able to leverage Spring's explicit dependency declaration using "depends-on" attribute in the "<beans/>" element, like so (from colocation-test code)...

  <context:component-scan base-package="com.gopivotal.colocation.test" />
 
 
 
  <gfe:cache/>
 
 
 
  <gfe:partitioned-region id="test2Region" name="test2" colocated-with="test1"/>
 
 
 
  <bean id="test2Template" class="org.springframework.data.gemfire.GemfireTemplate" p:region-ref="test2Region" depends-on="test1Template"/>
 
 
 
  <gfe:partitioned-region id="test1Region" name="test1"/>
 
 
 
  <bean id="test1Template" class="org.springframework.data.gemfire.GemfireTemplate" p:region-ref="test1Region"/>
 
on="test1Template"/>

Notice the 2 bean definitions (test1Template, test2Template) using the org.springframework.data.gemfire.GemfireTemplate class to setup access to the 2 GemFire Regions (test1 and test2, respectively). The "test2Template" defines a dependency on the "test1Template" for the test1 Region, thereby causing the beans to be created in the appropriate order, even for the arbitrary injection order.

The snippet of Spring configuration meta-data above also illustrates another point... that the proper bean creation order is not dependent on declaration order defined in the Spring app ctx configuration file since the bean definitions for Region test2 (the dependent, colocated Region) is defined/declared before Region test1.

The MyService class then becomes...

package com.gopivotal.colocation.test;
 
 
 
import javax.annotation.Resource;
 
 
 
import org.springframework.data.gemfire.GemfireTemplate;
 
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;
 
 
 
@Service
 
@SuppressWarnings("unused")
 
public class MyService {
 
 
 
  //@Resource(name = "test2Region")
 
  //private Region<String, String> test2;
 
 
 
  @Resource
 
  private GemfireTemplate test1Template;
 
 
 
  //@Resource(name = "test1Region")
 
  //private Region<String, String> test1;
 
 
 
  @Resource
 
  private GemfireTemplate test2Template;
 
 
 
  public void describe() {
 
    System.out.printf("test1Template configured with Region (%1$s)%n", test1Template.getRegion().getName());
 
    System.out.printf("test2Template configured with Region (%1$s)%n", test2Template.getRegion().getName());
 
  }
 
 
 
}

The code now leads to the desired result when started...

...
 
test1Template configured with Region (test1)
 
test2Template configured with Region (test2)
 
Waiting...

I have attached the modified version of the "colocation-test" app for convenience.
Attached colocation-test example application modified (colocation-test-mod.zip) to resolve issues identified with GemFire's Region colocation.
Both assigned this issue to myself as well as downgraded the severity to "critical" since there is an demonstrated workaround.

After discussing the proposed workaround above with Tim, Tim feels he would not present this to the customer as an acceptable solution in the interim, until an appropriate solution can be built into Spring Data GemFire.

Also, while I stand by what I stated above about using the GemfireTemplate in-place of directly referencing the Region class from the GemFire public API in application component classes, at it directly couples the application classes and components to the underlying data management technology, the proposed workaround also is not void of limitations.

If the <context:component-scan> element is moved to the end of the Spring configuration file, like so...


  <gfe:cache/>
 
 
 
  <gfe:partitioned-region id="test2Region" name="test2" colocated-with="test1"/>
 
 
 
  <bean id="test2Template" class="org.springframework.data.gemfire.GemfireTemplate" p:region-ref="test2Region" depends-on="test1Template"/>
 
 
 
  <gfe:partitioned-region id="test1Region" name="test1"/>
 
 
 
  <bean id="test1Template" class="org.springframework.data.gemfire.GemfireTemplate" p:region-ref="test1Region"/>
 
 
 
  <context:component-scan base-package="com.gopivotal.colocation.test" />

Then the application again will fail to start with...


Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Region specified in 'colocated-with' is not present. It should be created before setting 'colocated-with' to this region.
 
	at com.gemstone.gemfire.internal.cache.PartitionAttributesImpl.validateColocation(PartitionAttributesImpl.java:582)
 
	at com.gemstone.gemfire.internal.cache.PartitionAttributesImpl.validateWhenAllAttributesAreSet(PartitionAttributesImpl.java:553)
 
	at com.gemstone.gemfire.cache.AttributesFactory.validateAttributes(AttributesFactory.java:1528)
 
	at com.gemstone.gemfire.cache.AttributesFactory.create(AttributesFactory.java:1404)
 
	at org.springframework.data.gemfire.RegionAttributesFactoryBean.afterPropertiesSet(RegionAttributesFactoryBean.java:38)
 
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.invokeInitMethods(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:1541)
 
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.initializeBean(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:1479)
 
	... 23 more

This can again be corrected by moving the GemfireTemplate definition and bean definition for Region test1 above the GemfireTemplate and bean definition for Region test2 (the dependent, colocated Region).

Again, this solution relies on the "depends-on" attribute of a bean definition to identify the correct bean creation order despite injection order. And, of course, DI cannot occur in Spring without the use of the <context:annotation-config> or <context:component-scan> elements in Spring configuration meta-data (XML).

See next comment for, perhaps, a more acceptable, cleaner solution.

Perhaps, a more acceptable, and certainly cleaner solution would be a better organization and separation of the Spring configuration meta-data. This solution is no different than having to properly structure the GemFire object (e.g. Region) element declarations in cache.xml file for GemFire since cache.xml suffers from the same problem, as demonstrated above.

This recommendation is sound advice for any application.

The GemFire and application configuration should be broken into separate configuration files, like so...


gemfire-config.xml

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
 
       xmlns:gfe="http://www.springframework.org/schema/gemfire"
 
       xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
 
       xsi:schemaLocation="
 
         http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-3.2.xsd
 
         http://www.springframework.org/schema/gemfire http://www.springframework.org/schema/gemfire/spring-gemfire-1.3.xsd
 
">
 
 
 
  <gfe:cache/>
 
 
 
  <gfe:partitioned-region id="test1Region" name="test1"/>
 
  <gfe:partitioned-region id="test2Region" name="test2" colocated-with="test1"/>
 
 
 
</beans>

And...


app-config.xml

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
 
       xmlns:context="http://www.springframework.org/schema/context"
 
       xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
 
       xsi:schemaLocation="
 
         http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-3.2.xsd
 
         http://www.springframework.org/schema/context http://www.springframework.org/schema/context/spring-context-3.2.xsd
 
">
 
 
 
  <import resource="datasource-context.xml"/>
 
 
 
  <context:component-scan base-package="com.gopivotal.colocation.test" />
 
 
 
</beans>

Notice in the gemfire-config.xml file, the colocated Region test2 is declared after the Region test1 that it depends on. Then app-config.xml "imports" this resource before the component-scan occurs, ensuring the dependencies and dependent resources are created properly, in the correct order by Spring as expected by GemFire. In addition, this still allows GemFire's Region beans to be directly injected into application component classes as before thereby directly relying on the GemFire public API (despite coupling). Furthermore, this configuration cleanly separates the application concerns into different configuration meta-data files.

Note, this problem is similar in nature to SGF-197.

I have attached the modified colocation-test application ZIP file for reference.
Attached colocation-test example application (colocation-test-cfg.zip) with the Spring configuration properly separated by concern.
The fix has not been integrated into the repo just yet.
